Colin Powell 's remarks In regard to the financial crisis, which Colin Powell called the candidates' "final exam," Colin Powell said John McCain appeared unsteady in dealing with it, while Barack Obama had excelled in handling the situation. Barack Obama displayed a steadiness, an intellectual curiosity Thursday, June 11, 2009 Barack Obama 's President Bush Pastor Says Jews, AIPAC Have Too Much Influence Over Barack Obama The Newport News( VA) Daily Press yesterday reported on a short, but controversial, interview by one of its reporters with Barack Obama 's former pastor, Jeremiah Wright . Barack Obama publicly broke with Jeremiah Wright and his Trinity United Church Of Christ in May 2008 after he earlier criticized remarks made by Jeremiah Wright . Asked yesterday if he had spoken with Barack Obama since the election, Jeremiah Wright said: Them Jews ain't going to let him talk to me. But the teams at Google are globally organized, so whatever changes are made probably won't be reflected in regional offices like the one in Cambridge. , Peter Rice confirmed there would be four judges on the show, two men and two women, but insisted Simon Cowell would not be making the final decision on who would appear on it. He said: There's great speculation. I think Simon Cowell is still meeting and trying to find the right mixture. It'll be four judges as it is in England- it's two men, two women, one of which will be Simon Cowell .' " Simon Cowell 's going to come to us and he's going to say, "This is who I would like the judges to be,' and we'll have a conversation about it. know, there's a lot of talk these days around here about where members of Congress are going to sit during the State of the Union address," Indiana Republican Mike Pence said recently on the House floor. Well, I've been in Congress for 10 years and I learned a long time ago, it doesn't really matter where you sit- it matters where you stand. . Satya Nadella replaces Microsoft veteran Bob Muglia as head of the highly profitable server business. Steve Ballmer took the unusual step in January of publicly announcing that he thought Muglia was no longer fit for the job. This is simply a recognition that all businesses go through cycles and need new and different talent to manage through those cycles, Steve Ballmer wrote at the time. While Steve Ballmer was vague about the reasons, analysts believed that the CEO had lost faith in Muglia's ability to lead the company into the next generation of enterprise computing.
